item.title: Paper facades
item.content:encoded:
I feel facades, screens, dividers are all spaces where graphics take shape and form in more obvious ways. This could be like walking into a graphic form or a pattern in order to create experiences and views that must be imagined but go beyond our own imagination.


Developing a form, then a pattern, applying it to a facades in two dimension and then creating it in three dimension with the same ethos. This was challenging and fun as it was a spontaneous time based exercise. It could serve as a basis for idea generation, which could then be further investigated in the larger context of experiencing and creating spaces.

item.title: Line, Form & Emotion
item.content:encoded:
Sometime around 2013, in one of the sessions while co-teaching with Mark Warner; I came across a beautiful simple exercise in understanding a line and it's emotive quality. And then Mark turned it on its head and played the role of an astrologer by reading the emotion behind the drawings students had made. Ever since, I have reached out to that exercise to help give direction to students on basics of drawing, evolving a style and any other place I can find for it.

After which, that day students painted to list of music curated by them and eventually made some art on t-shirts, shoes and other unimaginable objects. The energy in the studio was exploding all the way out to the terrace and parapets. They painted with their hands, their feet, even blindfolded. 

Some images from over the years of sharing this with students at SPA.

item.title: "Drawing the root of everything" Van Gogh
item.content:encoded:
Academic Development and Innovation, Pearl Academy - Offline - Drawings, Delhi Chapter
Aug 2019 – Aug 2019
“Drawing the root of everything” Van Gogh

ADI is headed by Prof. Sharmila Katre, Agat Sharma - Associate Dean - Innovation and Design Strategy, Pearl Academy requested me to curate this event. This particular session was a conversation around the role of drawing as a means of learning and practice. The focus was how drawing acts as a tool while we learn, teach and work. Speakers had a diverse background, from architecture, fashion, product, photography, governance; they were educators, technicians, designers, administrators. It was truly wonderful to see how drawing helped them solve problems and communicate ideas.

Speakers: Dr. Badrinarayanan Srinivasan | John Edwards

Tripti Gupta | Vinod Maurya | Neha Dimri | Punkaran Singh

item.title: Unsplash!
item.content:encoded:
https://unsplash.com/@sagosago

It's time to give back. 
Thank you, Unsplash; for giving me wonderful images for my presentations and posters.
Now it's time, I give back to the community.

Starting with 3 images from Ladakh.

© Urvi Khanna

item.title: Can I surprise myself and stay calm?
item.content:encoded:
The desire to be calm in the midst of a thunder storm. Can I do it - be calm?

Life's Grey is a series of drawings inspired from the idea of looking at life beyond black and white, beyond wrong and right.

item.title: Life's Grey - A series of drawings on Art Finder
item.content:encoded:
Life's Grey is a series of drawings inspired from the idea of looking at life beyond black and white, beyond wrong and right. Its about allowing and addressing grey areas. Also an attempt at accepting life as it happens, its about change and how we cope with it. Yes, its about all that is unpleasant, ugly, hard, hidden yet truthful. Maybe grey is like Maya in Indian Philosophy - the enticing web of life.

https://in.pinterest.com/urvikhanna/urvis-original-art/

item.title: The Design Environment/Culture Module
item.content:encoded:
August was when it all really began.. All the planning, creating the curriculum, reworking details, dates, assignments was going play itself out, have a life of its own. Creating is magical in itself but, once a product starts to function and make meaning in everyday life - its satisfying. Maybe satisfaction is key to ones performance and sometimes simple things like students enjoying a class is enough. Enough to keep a teacher motivated.

Well, this post was going to be about the module I have begun to teach - so lets get back to that! Falling in an area of Praxis and yet being rooted in theory, its not an easy subject for foundation students to grasp. The general notion that doing design involves no studying of text books doesn't help either.

Design Environment is all about understanding the evolution of design through the theory and practice of design; by exploring context set in various cultures, aesthetics, socio-political, economic, environmental conditions.
So I thought of beginning the class from the idea of the self and then moving onto society. Class was all about expressing the idea of the self through words and then ideas that mattered in their lives through drawings. It culminated in an essay of 500 words on and person/object/place/idea that they cared about.

The writings were insightful, moving, truthful and innocent. What joy!

item.title: Indian Institute of Art & Design: The first batch of students arrives
item.content:encoded: After 6 months of joining Indian Institute of Art & Design, today the college was full of students! A sight we all had been working and waiting for.. It has been a real learning to say the least. To be a part of something new is always exciting and challenging. Feel lucky to be working with some very fine people, including the team in London. Let the journey begin!

item.title: Tales from Andretta
item.content:encoded:
A workshop held at NCFA, Woodlands Society Andretta from 6th-9th June 2015 by Urvi Khanna for children on story making. A small group of children from 5 to 14 years participated with great enthusiasm over the four days ending with a performance on the last day. 

We started with stories they knew and moved on to stories from their own experiences of school, travels, desires, fears and joys. Working at NCFA is a special experience, view of the mountains, cool breeze, bird sounds, happiness!..

item.title: What Dream Maps are made of?
item.content:encoded:
The significance of Art in Architecture is a constant debate. How much of art should be included in an architecture school, how much is too much. The kinds of exercises to be included. The importance of skill today... You may say or do anything but art creeps in!!!

In one of my second year studios at School of Planning and Architecture Delhi, we did this exercise -seemingly simple yet visually magical. The premise was that you could take any terrain, place, thing from anywhere in the world and make your dream map. These are some work in progress drawings done by my students. Enjoy!

item.title: 3 Monkeys
item.description: 1 comments captured from original post on Blogger CanvasJet said on 2019-05-28 It's a nice art, Which you have shared here about the…
item.content:encoded:
Monkeys are everywhere in summers -- even in the cities. They seem to be in a state of total bliss, abandon and frolic.

"3 Monkeys/ Oil on Canvas / 36"x 36" / Original painting by Urvi Khanna"

1 comments captured from original post on Blogger

CanvasJet said on 2019-05-28

It's a nice art, Which you have shared here about the 3 Monkeys. Your painting is very important for those who are looking to buy this art type painting at online. I would like to thanks for sharing this post here. Canvas Printing Dubai

item.title: Sheep Family in the Himalayas
item.content:encoded:
While trekking towards Triund in Himalayas, we encountered an infant sheep being ferried up the mountain by shepherd boys, to be reunited with its mother.

"Himalayan Sheep Family / 30"x20" / Oil on canvas / Original painting by Urvi Khanna"

It was such an inspiring moment that I had to paint it.

item.title: Self-expression Art Workshop at NCFA Andretta
item.content:encoded:
Self-expression Art Workshop held at NCFA, Woodlands Society Andretta on 15th June 2013 by Urvi Khanna. Organised as a part of Tripta Batra's contemplative thinking workshop held annually at Deer Park Institute, Bir.

The aim of the workshop was to facilitate participants to rediscover the child within, connect with their latent emotions, and express themselves spontaneously on a grand canvas using natural local materials like mud, leaves, twigs and colors.

item.title: Cleaning Up The Park
item.content:encoded:
A workshop held at NCFA, Woodlands Society Andretta on 9th June 2013 by Urvi Khanna assisted by Amba Sanyal, based on reuse of plastic bottle waste for making toys. Ridding the park of plastic bottles left behind by visitors!

The emphasis of the workshop was to initiate children into expressing their imaginative world and their dream images. The toys were entirely conceived, constructed, painted by the children between the ages of 3.5 to 15 yrs with minimal skill guidance. The workshop structure allowed the children to think outside the boundaries of stereotypical image making.

item.title: Play at Mirambika School, Delhi
item.content:encoded: The animal kingdom, a dried lake, a train, clouds, rain, the sun and about 20 sets of parents - all descended under a banyan tree in Mirambika on a summer morning to stage a play for the little 3-5 year old children. The children enjoyed the play and finally took a ride with the animals. And ever since have been asking for a play everyday. They even walk in and out of the school pretending to be one of the animals. My son helped me paint the train engine that he adores. This is such a wonderful way of learning, can't wait to try it out with kids both young and old!

item.title: Linocut and the Senses
item.content:encoded: Such an exciting sight -- lino prints on the walls, out to dry. Done by second year students of SPA Delhi, these artworks explore the concept of the 5 senses. The focus was not the conventional idea of senses but their individual experience and interpretation of it.

item.title: A Leaf and a Toothbrush
item.content:encoded: This child just created this beautiful work with a leaf, some paint and a toothbrush.

item.title: Samarpan Foundation
item.content:encoded: Patrick San Francesco and his team at the Samarpan Foundation are doing a great job! The children's home in New Delhi was bustling with energy. Children speaking fluently in english and hindi, polite, confident... Bright rooms, bunk beds, play area, a computer, didi's to take care of them! All dressed so well that they had to change for the art session that I  was to conduct. After which we all had some lovely lunch and they went on to doing their homework.

item.title: Arts & Graphics at School of Planning & Architecture
item.content:encoded:
Life drawing for beginners... work done by first year architecture students at School of Planning & Architecture, New Delhi. This is a class hosted by some esteemed friends and colleagues of mine.

This exercise generated so much excitement that students of all classes wanted to participate, including an art class I am co-hosting as visiting faculty for second year students.

item.title: The Writer's Block Interviews: Urvi Khanna
item.content:encoded:
My book The Fountain featured on 'The Writer's Block':
The Writer's Block is a blog by Raychelle Muhammad, a self-published author and book reviewer, who writes on a wide variety of health and wellness topics including urban gardening, interior design, and cooking.

item.title: On Blogger
item.content:encoded:
So my move to Blogger from a self-hosted wordpress blog is complete. Images you upload in your post directly go to your Picasa account and get served via the Google CDN. I've also integrated the website of my advertising firm into my blog -- since the idea of a company website was to primarily showcase portfolio.  Less time spent on software management and more time for the fun stuff!
Illustration above is from my picture-book 'The Fountain', available on the iTunes store for $0.99 only.

item.title: The Fountain - A Picture Book
item.content:encoded:
Reviews:
(5-star review) "Lovely pictures. And with sound too! A great telling of the important journey of water."
- Dan Amos, via iTunes Store UK (June 11, 2012) 
"This is a beautiful story about nature for young kids… Personally, as a grandma, I LOVE IT! My 5 year old granddaughters first impression was 'awwwesome….!'"
- theemptynestexpress.com (June 10, 2012)
Today is World Environment Day and it's a pleasant coincidence that my first (co-authored) Picture eBook for children, which is on nature, came online on the Apple iBookstore today.
It's called The Fountain, and right now it's available on 30 stores at the iBookstore, including USA ($ 0.99), UK, and several other countries in Europe (€ 0.99). You can download a sample before buying, or view the screenshots to get an idea of the content. The book can be viewed in iBooks2 on Apple iPad, iPhone or iPod Touch. Here's a paragraph from the book description:

Description
"A small fountain / Sprouts / In the mountain". Children love nature, and they love water fountains. From waterfalls, to oceans, thunderstorms, and geysers; this beautifully illustrated and poetically written color picture book explores awe-inspiring sights and sounds from some of earth's most exciting natural phenomena.
Not available in India yet
Unfortunately, we aren't able to distribute this in India yet due to some policy restrictions by Apple. We'll be releasing an India-specific version soon through another channel.

iBooks - A robust way of publishing interactive books
Given all the restrictions with the iBookstore, the fact is that iBooks is currently the most robust available platform for publishing interactive books for children. Our book has various sound effects and interactive elements and during our research we could not find a better substitute.

Inspiration
For me, living in a polluted city like New Delhi with a toddler has been challenging as a parent -- as one is always looking at finding avenues of interaction with nature, for your child. Last month I've been conducting a children's workshop called Art in the Park, and for me this book is a natural progression to that.

More to come
According to some recent media reports, nature has increasingly been absent from kids' books. Here is our contribution to the cause of bringing environment and nature back into books -- The Fountain is the first book in our series of Nature Books and you may expect several more in the series. Hope your kids enjoy it! Any feedback is more than welcome as it will help us improve for the subsequent books.

Free giveaways to early reviewers
I'm giving a few copies of this ebook free to early reviewers. If you'd like to get one, please email me / leave a comment with your email id and I'll send you a coupon code that will allow you to download this book free on your iOS device.

Download details
Book Title: The Fountain
ISBN: 9781621544494
Authors: Urvi Khanna, Indie Poe
Pages: 16
Platform: iBooks / iOS
Type: Picture e-Book with audio effects
Available on Apple iTunes Stores: US, UK, DE, ES, FR, IT, NL, AT, SE, CH, DK, BE, FI, IE, PL, NO, HU, GR, CZ, CY, LU and several other countries.

item.title: Freedom of the Mind
item.content:encoded:
"I know but one freedom and that is the freedom of the mind." - Antoine de Saint-Exupéry
Last session (Day 6) of Art in the Park was held last Friday. It was designed as a free-play, paint, and collaborate session on a grand canvas.
It's pretty tricky to get a bunch of toddlers and young kids to collaborate -- it's an organic process, really. Luckily, copious amounts of vibrant non-toxic paint and a large white canvas that you can float over are good catalysts.
The ball gets rolling at once as the children dive in to get their hands (and feet, and faces) dirty.
It's almost like some awesome form of speed-painting.
Above and below - the final output of the group painting exercise. Beautiful stuff!
Afterwards, the children split up and went on to create their own independent works, showcased below:
The whole experience of conducting this workshop was awesome, I will write a detailed introspective post about that soon.

item.title: In the Finding Out
item.content:encoded:
"The true delight is in the finding out rather than in the knowing." - Isaac Asimov
Day 5 of Art in the Park held last Friday was all about discovering depth, dimension and texture.
The idea was to sketch / paint the invisible or the hidden, along with the visible.
Often, one can discover the hidden mysteries of nature by looking hard enough; at other times you can only experience them by obtaining an impression.
These impressions may not represent absolute reality, but the artist's personal journey of discovery makes them more than real.
Above are some of the art works produced by the workshop participants using an improvised linocut printmaking technique.

item.title: Like the Flower
item.content:encoded:
"Be like the flower, turn your face to the sun." - Kahlil Gibran
Day 4 (held last Friday) of Art in the Park.

The grass was the canvas, and flowers the colors.
Out came a butterfly.
The children carried some sunflower seeds back home. In case you are looking at planting some, here's a how-to guide I found on the web.

item.title: A Series of Small Things
item.content:encoded:
"Great things are done by a series of small things brought together." - Vincent Van Gogh
So, Day 3 of Art in the Park and the workshop participants seem to be enjoying pushing a few boundaries. If you haven't already, check out the posts about Day 1 and Day 2 sessions.
As usual, things start with a nondescript line or a splash of paint.
And then stuff starts happening fast.
Forms appear, elements get added, more paint gets splashed around.
Characters get life.
"Caterpillar", by a 6-year old:
"Butterfly", by a 3-year old:
"Dancing Person", by an 8-year old:
"Ipad & Sticks", by a 2.5 year old:
Things seem to be warming up. The neem tree is, as usual, keeping it cool for us.

item.title: A Receptacle for Emotions
item.content:encoded:
”The artist is a receptacle for emotions that come from all over the place: from the sky, from the earth, from a scrap of paper, from a passing shape, from a spider's web.” - Pablo Picasso
Today we carried forward the theme from the first session of Art in the Park initiative for young children.
The children explored shape, structure and dynamics of natural elements through a mix of materials.
The outcome was amazing.
Art works produced by 2.5 to 3.5 year old children out of their own spontaneity and volition, with a bit of encouragement and guidance.

item.title: The Influence of Nature
item.content:encoded:
"In the beginning you must subject yourself to the influence of nature. You must be able to walk firmly on the ground before you start walking on a tightrope." - Henri Matisse
Art in the Park series for children aims to explore this beautiful philosophy. Today was the very first session. A few sights that greeted us when we entered Lodhi Gardens:
Majestic trees, vibrant green grass, the chirping of birds - could be a perfect day for picnic. And we were carrying a picnic basket as well.
We explored around for a bit: seeing, smelling, listening and touching; singing and telling stories at the same time. Then we just went and splashed it all out on our art-boards.
This was it, today:
Had fun today. See you again on Friday!

item.title: Art in the Park
item.content:encoded:
Finally looks like we are going to start again with a new season of Arty-doodle-do! Last time we did 4 sessions in Nizamuddin Community Center and had a blast.
This time we'll be holding the sessions outdoors at Lodhi Gardens. Art in the Park, that's what it is! Beautiful atmosphere, fresh air, lovely light, children, some art and loads of fun.
There are 2 time slots to choose from:
Slot 1 (9.00 - 10.00 AM on Wednesdays): 9 May / 16 May / 23 May / 30 May / 6 June
Slot 2 (9.00 - 10.00 AM on Fridays): 11 May / 18 May / 25 May / 1 June / 8 June

Venue: Lodhi Gardens (near the pond, under the group of old trees)
All materials will be provided. Limited class size.
Workshop is structured as 4-sessions.

Notes:
- The age group is right from 2.5 to 6 years, so siblings can join together... and yet do their own thing.
- Children should be accompanied by a care giver.
- They may carry a water bottle, a small snack, and a picnic mat.
- Clothes may get stained or dirty during activities, children may wear something accordingly.

For any queries / suggestions or registration, please email urvikhanna@gmail.com, or use the comments form below.

item.title: In the Thick of Paint!
item.content:encoded:
Paint, paint and more paint, on little feet, hands, faces and some on paper. They simply love it, there are some who take their time to get into the thick of paint but once they overcome their fears there is no stopping them. We all had a blast and my son just can't get enough of these classes.
Over the four weeks they experimented with various mediums and experienced art together. One child's words can start a chain reaction of events, they act and react to all that is around them, its so unpredictable and creative! Their minds are buzzing and hands itching to do, its a challenge to keep up.

item.title: B.C. Sanyal Marg
item.content:encoded: Today the 3rd of January 2012, B.C. Sanyal Marg was unveiled by Shri Paramjeet Singh, Shri Som Benegal and Shri R.K. Anand at the Nizamuddin East round about near Khan Khana's tomb in New Delhi, India. A beautiful morning with smiling familiar faces, remembering Baba and Amma! We love you.

item.title: Arty-doodle-do for Toddlers
item.content:encoded:
Arty-doodle-do:  the art experience program for learning and expressing through art for toddlers from 1.5 to 3 years of age is open for registrations. Each session is designed to stimulate their imaginations and promises something new and exciting. It aims to create a friendly, supportive environment for self expression through art. They will experiment with various art materials, art processes develop some skills and have fun while doing so!

All materials will be provided, either a parent or caregiver can accompany the toddler for the duration of the session.

Currently the sessions will be held at Nizamuddin East, New Delhi Community Center.
Once a week
Duration: 1 hr
Total 4 sessions

For any queries / suggestions or registration, please email urvikhanna@gmail.com or post a comment or registration request here.

item.title: Children's Art Program
item.content:encoded:
Arty-doodle-do™ is the name of a new art experience program I am designing for preschoolers and toddlers. It's a kind of art initiation program that deals with experiencing art in it's various forms and not just concentrating on creating objects.

Art can be a powerful tool for self expression while being total fun. Children can learn about their environment and share their experiences through art and learn to cooperate and collaborate. The program also aims to develop communication and motor skills; fuel their imagination and expose them to the various possibilities with art.

item.title: Inventiv Advertising: Creative Services for Brands
item.description: 1 comments captured from original post on Blogger Paperown said on 2018-02-15 You left me wowed, I feel luck I found your website. Keep…
item.content:encoded:
Inventiv Advertising is a consulting firm providing creative ideas and cross-domain solutions for brand development, marketing and management.
Inventiv constantly innovates to conceive and implement solutions using latest marketing, media and technology methods to solve business challenges in the areas of marketing and branding.

Services & Methodologies:
Brand Management including strategy, identity, extensions, termination; using a proprietary methodology called ‘Formulated Approach to Memorable Brand Experiences (Inventiv-FAB™)’, which extends the industry standard Brand Identity Prism model by Kapferer to include more experiential facets of a brand.

Tactical Planning using proprietary methodology called ‘Tactical Integrated Marketing & Advertising Plan (Inventiv-TiMAP™)’ helps clients define short-term objectives based on brand strategy, develop advertising metrics and research parameters, and lay out a roadmap comprising of cost and revenue projections based on media and production plans.

Creative Strategy based on the keyword ‘different’. A totally unique creative strategy supports even focus-driven marketing strategies, creating differentiation as a generic rule rather than choice.

Market Research both quantitative and qualitative, forming an important part of the tactical plan. Feedback cycle feeds the ongoing creative process for corrections in the Creative Strategy.

Liberated Advertising Media-mix (Inventiv-LAMP), a proprietary methodology that integrates tactical planning with  new media communication channels — organic search marketing, search-engine marketing, social media marketing and viral m-marketing.

Experiential Campaign Lifecycle Management (Inventiv-ECLM™), a proprietary methodology for prolonging the experience that a target consumer has with an advertising message, by targeting the end-user at various touch-points encountered by the individual at various times of her normal working day.

1 comments captured from original post on Blogger

Paperown said on 2018-02-15

You left me wowed, I feel luck I found your website. Keep producing the great content Assignment writing services in UK

item.title: Time Arcade
item.content:encoded: For Time Arcade a project that offers an optimal mix of retail, office and leisure spaces, conceived & designed the logo and marketing collateral.

item.title: The Tandoor
item.content:encoded: The Tandoor - an Indian restaurant in China. Rebranding The Tandoor experience with a new advertising campaign in the local media.

item.title: Mobile Creches
item.content:encoded:
Amidst roars of construction machinery, a small group of children walking in a single file make their way to a makeshift compound surrounded by corrugated tin sheets. This is going to be their haven for the remainder of the day.
This place is run by an NGO called Mobile Creches and is more than a day care center -- it is a functioning school to a large extent. None of the kids are carrying schoolbags though -- indeed, several of the older children are carrying their infant siblings in their arms. Their parents are daily laborers working at construction sites nearby.

item.title: Ikat: The Way of the Weaver
item.content:encoded:
A magazine assignment has taken me to Nuapatna, Orissa - home to hundreds of traditional Ikat weavers. These weavers live extremely fulfilling lives in spite of surviving by modest means. Ikat weaving as a craft has been handed down generations, and is under threat similar to many other cottage crafts. "The times they are a-changin'", so said Bob Dylan.

The village surroundings are picturesque and easy on the eyes. Both the houses and common spaces of the village are usually kept clean. Adults and children likewise seem to be in a cheerful mood. It does feel like they love what they do. Oh, and there's cricket!
The challenging part has been to photograph the workspaces where the actual weaving is done. The rooms with the looms are only dimly lit because the weavers can't afford the power. Getting the right exposure to catch the rhythmic motion of a weaver's loom was difficult. Some of the images below have been shot in near dark conditions.
The whole process of creating an Ikat sari is lengthy and complex. You need to make the yarn, dye it, dry it and then weave it.
The weavers are a passionate and proud lot. Sometimes, a sari may take years to complete. The devotion to the craft is inspirational. This is the way of the Ikat weaver.

item.title: In Perspective: Jantar Mantar Revisited
item.content:encoded:
After photographing Jantar Mantar over the course of many days, I sat down to review the ton of images I had collected. The more I studied the pictures, the more intrigued I became by the complexity and character of the space. My mind was awash with creative imagery and it became fairly obvious to me that I needed to express some of these ideas through a physical medium.
Some of the results of this ongoing work using mixed media on paper are presented below.

item.title: Dhoot Group
item.content:encoded: A corporate brochure, but more like a vision document for a rapidly growing business conglomerate.

item.title: Lost in Perspective
item.description: 2 comments captured from original post on Blogger Abhiroop Banerjee said on 2012-09-13 Hi! Where can I see larger pictures please? These…
item.content:encoded:
Jantar Mantar in New Delhi is a natural observatory that was built in the 18th century to prepare astronomical tables and calculate time based on the movement of the sun. It can be used to estimate time of day to a fairly accurate degree even today. For a photographer this is a pretty exciting building. It's maze like design offers ample opportunities to capture the interplay of angles and spaces.

2 comments captured from original post on Blogger

Abhiroop Banerjee said on 2012-09-13

Hi! Where can I see larger pictures please? These look brilliant.

urvi khanna said on 2012-10-12

Thanks, not available online at the moment. Nice to hear from you!

item.title: Tradespotting Old Delhi
item.content:encoded:
Chandni Chowk area of Old Delhi seems to be frozen in time, while the world around this island of civilisation has moved on. A visit to Chandni Chowk usually forms an essential milestone in the itinerary of a first time visitor to Delhi, especially if you're searching for the sights, sounds and smells of India as described in the guide books of an era gone by.
On a few afternoons I went around 'Tradespotting Old Delhi' -- documenting the life of various businesses and the people behind the trades. Much of the work is done manually; from carrying heavy loads on shoulders to ferrying people across in rickshaws.

item.title: Autsun.com
item.content:encoded: Branding, website and direct mail for e-commerce company.

item.title: Vistara: 150-acre Modern Integrated Township
item.content:encoded: Inventiv created an integrated marketing campaign for the upcoming township project by Suncity and Dhoot Group in Indore, a tier-2 city in Central India.

item.title: ICare Eye Hospital
item.content:encoded: Inventiv helped the charitable eye hospital ICARE raise funds from large institutions through insightful, strategic marketing communication.

item.title: Road, Movie
item.content:encoded: Promotional material and pre-production support for award winning movie by acclaimed film maker Dev Benegal. Official selection at Atelier, Cannes 2006.

item.title: Time Tower
item.content:encoded: For Dhoot Developers, conceived and executed a complete all-round multimedia campaign comprising of an international short film, brand strategy, tactical advertising plan and creative strategy, to create and develop a real-estate brand.

item.title: Corporate Film for Time Tower
item.content:encoded: A creative 6 minute corporate film for Time Tower that blends 3D walk-through with real footage, meant to provide prospective buyers with a feel for what the eventual project would look like.

item.title: La Lagune
item.content:encoded: Inventiv helped Suncity Projects create a product and brand strategy for a new real-estate project that became an input for project's architecture, besides other things.

item.title: How to Drive a BMW into a Wall of Glass
item.content:encoded:
Sometimes, advertising people can indulge in their evil fantasies and still be rewarded. Like this shoot for a short film we did, that required crashing a BMW into a wall of glass. So, if you're shooting a relatively low budget film, how does one do that with a rented 30 Lacs car without getting a single scratch on the body (both car and human)?
Luckily, we had some very smart production people from Mumbai who stage managed everything to perfection. Using a combination of sugar glass and low grade explosives, the effect of smashing the car into the glass wall was achieved successfully.

Except, the irony of all things  - the shot didn't make it into the final cut of the film for creative reasons!

item.title: Action Medical Institute
item.content:encoded: Creating a brand identity for a medical institute and hospital is an extemely challenging task. Inventiv went back to the basics to connect with evergreen human emotions.

item.title: Pilgrimage in Satara: A River Runs Through It
item.content:encoded: Every year, in a remote part of Satara district in Maharashtra, peasant communities from around the area arrive in thousands for a pilgrimage to the shrine of the local deity. They come wearing one pair of clothes and no possessions. The river parts, and the riverbed island plays host to a three day long festival of fun, color, food, traveling cinema, joy rides and much more.

item.title: Firefox Bikes
item.content:encoded: Inventiv helped Firefox maximize its ROI from a small communications budget by investing in viral marketing and interactive media.

item.title: Amritsari Rang
item.content:encoded: Inventiv helped Foresight Group bring the colors and spices of Amristar to New Delhi's taste buds through a host of branding and marketing activities.

item.title: Spaveda
item.content:encoded: Inventiv helped create, package and launch a new personal care brand in a crowded FMCG category.

item.title: 24x7 Making Movies
item.content:encoded: For his ground-breaking movie production program, acclaimed filmmaker Dev Benegal relied on Inventiv to create a youth-friendly multimedia website that showcased the short-films churned out by the participants in 24 hours.

item.title: Ananda In The Himalayas
item.content:encoded: When the world's #1 spa wanted to attract Indian audiences, Inventiv helped them reach out with the right tools.

item.title: The Chinese
item.content:encoded: Inventiv provided a turnkey 360-degree marketing solution for the Indian launch of UK based hospitality group Foresight. From brand identity, ambient advertising, press, radio and outdoor advertising to staff uniforms and public relations, Inventiv helped The Chinese develop a customer base in a short-span of one month.

item.title: Bar Menu for The Chinese
item.content:encoded: Bar Menu design for The Chinese, based on traditional Chinese symbols, poetry and culture.

item.title: Outdoor Campaign for The Chinese
item.content:encoded: If you're having trouble answering some of these questions, please visit The Chinese and study the menu.

item.title: Food Menu for The Chinese
item.content:encoded:
Excerpt from the menu:
"630 A.D.
An oasis in the middle of Taklimakan Desert.

Caravan trade routes from China to the West - mysterious, fascinating and full of the promise of good fortune.

On route to Isfahan, passing the cities of Xian, Lanzhou, Dunhuang, Turfan, Urumqi and stopping by the oasis town of Kashgar.

With goods stacked high to the heavens, merchant caravans camp next to the water, cooking their favorite meal… The Chinese".

— From the Chronicles of the Chinese Trader

item.title: R S Exports
item.content:encoded: Inventiv helped RSE generate an international quality communication in 72 hours. This included a product shoot at the client's site, brochure design, as well printing of just a few high quality copies for circulation.
